1t is the custom in boarding houses 10 give no.
tce ofthc hour Of meals BY ringing bell. A
cat belonging to the house, being accustomed to
get his food in the dining room, soon became At.
tentiyc to the sound that summoned the family
to othe parlor II happened one day that he had
been shut upin room, and was therefore pre-
vented from attending to the voice of the anx-
iously expected bell; and on being released from
his prison some hours after, he immediately has.
tened to the dining room; but unfortunately eve
ry thing had disappeared, and the poor cat found
himself obliged 70 go without his breakfast To
wards the middle Of the day the bell was sudden
ly heard ringing; and on the servants running out
TO ascertain the cause, they found the cat hang.
ing by the rope, and sunlmoning the family to a
second repast!
INSTINCT.

Owing to the scarcity Of Corn in this sec
tion OF the country, no doubt many expedi-
ents VIII be adopted to prevent its consump-
ton we Yesterday heard o. one, which we
trust, for the credit of tho State, and for the
sake OF humanity, stands alone; but we think
It ought to be mentioned, that travellers
may be put on their guard A gentleman
stopped at a house in an adjacent county.
which promised "entcrtainment tor man
and beast" and requested that his horse
might be ted. Before ordering him out to
resume his Journey, he Went to the stable to
see how he Jared and was surprised to find,
that though there was sufficicncy of corn
and fodder before him, he had eat nothing. He
was at loss to account for this voluntary
abstinence, and putting his hand into the
trough to ascertain the cause, he found the
bottom OF It nicely coated With fresh Tar. 1t
was spread ON so thinly as to be impercept


ble to the eye, but it is known that the
horse has such great antpathy to this sub
stance, that he will touch nothing imnrcp-
mated Will. t.-hcgister.

We do not positively know, however,
whether any conquests were made on either
side; but we thought now and then, that
"love has eyes" And once, when gen
tleman whose struggling tell-tale hairs had
disappeared for the evening, and received
some kind and f1attering expressions from a
nymph of laughing eye and carnation lips,
we thought, from the life and Joy which
it seemed to have impaired. that the gentle
swain, had he been poetical, would have ex
claimed:--


"Speak to me thus and will be loves slave;
Pll build him altars-hc shall have all flowers
Of vale, or hill, or fountain and all fruits
That melt in Autumn's basket; nay, the gold
ot ilcsperls' gardenwere too Slight y gift

The following aneedoteisquoted froh the
new Philadelphia Quarterly. The review
of American Biography, from winch thls Is
taken, containsa number of interesting lncl-
dents and characters.


When the British army had possession OF
Philadelphia, Gen. Howe's headquarters
were in Second d-street, the fourth door below
Spruce in house which was before occupi-
ed by Gen. Cadwallader Directly oppo-
site, resided William and Lydia Darrah,
members of the society of Friends. A supe-
rlor officer of the British Army, believed to
be the adjutant General, fixed upon one OF
their chambers, a back room, for private
conference and two Of them frequently met
there, with fire and candles in close consul
taton. About the ID Of December, the adj
iutant general told Lydia that they would be
in the room at o'clock, and remain late;
and that they wished the family to retire
early to bed; adding that when they were
going away they would call her to let them
out, and extinsuish their fire and candles.
She accordingly sent all the family to bed;
but as the officer had been SO particular, her
curiosity was excited.


She took off her shoes. and put her ear to
the key -holc of the conclave, and overheard
an order read for all the British troops to
march out late in the evening of the fourth,
and attack General Washngton's army,
then encamped at White Marsh. On hear
ing this she returned to her chamber, and
laid down. Soon after, the officers knock ed
at the door, but She rose only at the third
summons, having teigned herself asleep.
Her mind was SO much agitated, that from
this moment. she could neither ca. nor sleep;
supposlng it to be III her power to save the
lives of thousands of her fellow countrymcn;
but not knowing how She was to convey the
Information to General Washington. not
dating to confdc il to her husband. The time
left, however, was short. She quickly de-
termned to make her way, as soon as posi-
Bile, to the American outposts. She inform
ed her family, that as she was in want Of
-four She would so to Franktord for some;
her husband insisted that she should take
the servant maid with her, but to his sur
prise she positively refused. She got acces.
70 General Howe, and solicited, what he
readily granted, apass through the British
troops on the lines. Leaving her bag at the
null, she FASTENED towards the American
lines, and encountered on her way an A.
merican lieutenant colonel (Craiy) OF the
light horse, who, with some OF his men, was
~ the look out for information. He knew
her, and inquired where she was going, She
answered, in quest Of her son, an officer in
the American army, and praying the colonel
% alisht and walk with her. He did so, or
derlng his troops to keep in sight. 10 him
She disclosed he, secret, after ha, ing obtain
ed from him solemn promise never To be-
tray her individually, as her life might be 1T
stake with the British.


He conducted hen To house near at hand,
directed something for her to eat, and has
tened 70 head quarters. when he brought
General Washington acquainted with what
he had heard. Washington made, Of course,
all preparation for battling the medtatetl sur
prise. LHdlA returned home With her flour;
sat up alone to watch the tnovtrnt nts If the
I'ritlsl. troops; heard their footsteps; but
when they returned in a few hours after, did
not dare TO ask QUESTION, though s0licitous
to know the event. The next evening the
Adlntant General came in, and requested
her 70 walk up to his room, AS he wished to
put some questions, She followed him in
terror; when he locked the door and begged
her, With an air Of mystery, to be seated
She va, sure she was either suspected or
hetrayed.-He inquired earnestly, whether
any Of her family were up the last night lie
and the other officer met; she told him thai
they all retired at O'Clock. lie Observed,
"l know you were asleep for | knocked al
your chamber door three times before Won
heard me: ! am entirely at loss to imagine
who gave Gen. WASHINGTON information Of
cur intended attack, unless the walls of the
house could speak.-Whcn we arrived near
White Marsh, we found all their cannon
mounted, and the troops prepared TO receive
US, and We have marched back like par
eel CT FOOLS

Ii viii be recolcotcd that at one Of the
meetings Of the venerable fraternity Of
bachelors {savs the Commercial Advcrtls-
er,) called for the purpose of resisting the
encroachment meditated on their rights, bv
the leading member of the legislature, it
was resolved to show the world that tbey
were not yet destitute Of life and soul and
public spirit, by giving bali. the proceeds
OF which should be devoted to the support of
the mothers and sisters of those bachelors
Of Greece, who are fighting the battles of
freedom and their country. From the lay
of the resolution until the consummation Of
the project. the fraternity have been as bu-
silly engaged in procuring decorations for the
Assembly Room, and rendering themselves
agreeable in the outward man, as though
they were about to lay siege to the whole
race of unmarried females at once. And to
do them justice, they succeeded to admira
ton The ball was got up with elegance
and splendor, and whether the bachelors re-
serted to the same stratagcm that the Ro-
man bachelors did when they made viii
/ ling captives of the Sabine women, or not
we cannot say; but certain it is, that those
Sabines must have had charming daughters
if their artiul after sons in-aw stole such ar
! assemhlsge of pretty women. The ball wa,
given at the City Hotel; and Mr.. Jennings
Being himself gay bachelor, spared nei
ther pains, nor labor, nor expense. in III,
preparations for sustaining the honor of hi.
brethren.


4 The ladies, certainly large majority o
them, to say nothing of the native charms o
beautiful forms, bright eyes, captivatin,
smiles and blooming cheeks. were arrayet
with good taste and elegant simplicity
White pretlominated, with head dresses O
flowers, feathers, pearls, and brlliants.
would be invidious to particularize; suffice i
then 20 say, that youth. and beauty, and love
liness, mingled in gay communioa. and the
slendid forms appeared like sylphs from
happier sphere, assembled to cheer the hun
dreds of gay bachelors. who from this chill
ling appellation have been supposed coli
and dead to the fasciua,ions Of that sc,,

shat OF Great Britaia in the East Indies. But |
40 one in rendering them this justice can
help taking interest in the fate of the Indians. |
EAus, meeting az every step the bark hut of
wandering hunter who inhabits it in secn |
rIty. ana III the simple virtues Of ignorance,
We cannot think without sorrow that they
viii soon be overturned and replaced by an
American cultipator's farm.


II was heara rapid creek, the borders OF which
we're Steep that we saw for the first time the In
dans united in a body to receive the General. A
great number ot women and young boys broke
through the trees on the opposite border Of the
aver, and, upon seeing rs, they raised cries Of
10Y. Some warriors descended the brow of
i.lll at little distance and to spot on the
river side where the boat was, iii which we were
20 land-Thc variety and singular richness Of
their costumes offered most picturesque view.
hlr George Lafayette splan!s first upon the land,
and III moment was surrounded by men, wo
incn and children, who moved round him, dane
ed about him, touched his hands and his garments
with an air Of surprise, and delight which caus
Cd him almost as much embarrassment rs emo.
ton Suddenly, as il they wished to give more
dgnhed and solemn expression to their Joy they
retired behind the men ranged in front. lie
who appeared to be the chief Of the tribe, By
shr and prolonged cry gave the signal for a sort
OF salute which was repeated by the whole troops
when they rushed again towards the boat.-Im-
mediately upon the Generals descending, some
of the strongest brought little low chair, which
we had with us, and obliged him to mount it,
"not wishing they said, shat their father
should put his foot on the damp earth.' The
General was thus carried as in a paanquin, to a
certain distance from the river side, then he
whom have already distinguished as the chief
Of the tribe approached, and told him in English,
that all his brothers were happy at being visited
by him, who in his affection for the inhabitants
of America, had never distinguished blood or
color; who was the cherished father OF mcn who
nhabitthe continent After the chief had spok
en-, the other Indians came to press the hand OF
the General and to place it on their heads. They
would not abandon the carriage, but dragged ii
themselves, mounted by short steps the hill from
which which we had seen them descend, and ON
which was situated one OF their largest hamets,


Whilst We walked, approached the Indian
Chief thought that, since lie spoke English, he
had been brought up like liamly in the United
States, and SO was informed lie was about 28
years of aye, Of middle size his limbs per
fectv beautiful, his phys,ognony noble, and hi,
airsorowfi.l. When he did not speak he cast
down his large black eyes, which were covered
With thick eyc-lashes. When he toll me that he
was the eldest son Of Macintosh, could not re-
cal, without pain, the mPrecations that | had
heard from the watch, against the Ctiet OF the
Maacogulges 1t was this, undoubtedly, which
gave the young man the air Of detection and
meditation; but, after what coali gather, from
his conversation, explained il to myself still
better his Intelligence only developed itself a
the expense ofhis security. lie appreciated the
true position fthis nation; he perceived it was
growing weaker, and forcsaw its approaching
distinctions he feh how inferior it was to those
which surrounded III he had learned how impos
slble it was to change the wandering lite ot men
of his race. The neighborhood ofclylzed men
had not done them any good, and had introduced
among them vices to which they we're strangers


He seemed to hope that the treaty, which cast
them back into country wholly desert, would
restore the ancient organization Of the tribes, or
at least guaranty their preservation in the state
n which they now were.


In the meantime. we arrived at the top Of the
hlll-there we saw helmets, and swords, and
horsemen, ranged along the road; they were
not Indians, but civilized men sent from the state
Of Alabama, to meet the General. The slngu-
lar triumphant march, to which he had been
obliged to submit, then ceased. The Indians
could not see without Jealousy. the American
escort place themselves around him; but we ap.
preached their village, and they hastened to
approach il before rs. There, at our afrval, we
found them met together, having thrown aside
their garments and prepared to exhibit before
rs their warlike games. We reached vast
plain, about which was scattered q hundred In.
dian habitations, improved BY the verdure Of the
thick groves We noticed house larger than
the others; it was that Of the American resident;
he at the same time kept an inn, and his wife had
the direction ofa school, in which they attempt
ed tc instruct the children Of the Indians All
the men were assembled in this place, having
thrown aside part Of their vestnents; their faces
painted with colors Enthusiastically mixed and some
wearing, by way Of distinction, plumes in their
hair, They told us that they were going to play
in honor Of their white father And we really
saw them separate into two armies, form two
camps in two extremities Oft the place, name two
chiefs, and provoke each other to combat. The
cry which was raised by each Of the two divisions,
and which they told us was the war-cry Of the
Indian tribes, is perhaps, the strongest modnla-
ton of the human voice, that it is possible to
hear, and the effect which it produced upon the
warriors, Young and old, is more extraordinary
still. The sports commenced-They explained
to us that the game was, for the two parties to
throw ball, something like that of our scholars,
10 certain mark, and that he who struck this
mark seven times should be victorious We in
reality saw the combatants, each armed with
two long and heavy rockets prcc tate them.
selves with light movement, leap one above
the other, in order to seize It in the air, with


unprecedented skill, and scnd il to the mark ~
when the ball was missed by player, it rolled
on the pround-Then they all lowered theil

It affords US much qualification to state, that
the Navy Department have promptly accecded
to the request of the Common Council Of this
city, 10 have the remains Of our fellow citizen,
Lieut.. WILLIAM II. ALLEN, brought from Ma.
taneas to New York, in a public vessel; and that
a Letter from MIR. Secretary Southland to the May.
or OF this city, assures him that the earliest op.
portnnity vii! be improved to have this service
pertorlncd in manner gratifying to the friends
and fellow citizens Of Lieut.. All, i, and with All
respect due to the memory Of the larnentcd he.

The Griswold Manufacturing Companys
Noollen Factory, at Jewett City, Conn. belong.
ing to Breed, Trumbull & White, was entirely
consumed, with the machinery and large GUAM
tlty Of stock, last Monday morning, The fire is
supposed to have originated from the stove
pipe in the third loft. Loss estimated at soOO 900
which was insured at Hartford.

On May day, 1913, there was shameful
riot committed by the London apprentices,
servants, watermen, and priests, against for
elgners, by pulling down and rining their
houses. The complaints against them were,
"that there were such numbers OF them EN-.
ployed as arttlcers, that the English could
set no work; that the English merchants
had little TO do, by reason of the merchant
strangers bringing in all silks cloths Of gold,
VINE, oil, iron; that no man almost buyeth OF
an Engllshman; they also export SO much
wool, tin. and lead, that English adventurers
can have no living; that foreigners compass
the city round about, in Southwark. West
minister, Temple Bar, Holborn, st. Martins,
st. John-Street. Aldgate. Tower Hill, and
st. GATHERINGS: and they forestall the mar
ket. 50 that no good thing for them cometh
TO the market, which are the causes why
Engiishmen want and starve, whilst foreign
ers live in abundance and pleasure that
the Dutchmen bring over Iron, timber, ana
leather ready manufactured, and nails, locks
baskets. cupboards, stools. tables, chests,
grdles. saddles, and painted cloths" y
saw" said John Lincoln, (the chief instigat-
or, )"on Sunday this Lent, six hundred Tor
eigners shooting At the poppinjay with cross
bows" This riot was over by dawn o. day
Several of the rioters were hanged. and the
King pardoned the rest. The pretenlea
crimes of these foreigners were, their WORK
ing cheaper and being more indusfrlom
than our o1ca teotle, whose exclusive PRIV.
ileges within the city kept the foreigners !"
those ont-ports above named. out OF the ires.
dom; thereby getting much Of the 'raoS
from the freemen.--.4nnais Of Commerce.

TIE Grec& .SuhiH SAln.-The elegant
ship Chancellor, Capt Baker hauled out in
the stream yesterday, and will probably sail
to-day, with provisions, &c. for the Greeks.
Mr.. Miller, of Vermont. who was three
years IN Greece, and eighteen months in ac-
tual service, goes out in the vessel He will
have the charge oi the supplies. and pay at
tentlon TO their distribution. The cargo is
SAID 70 be worth $4,000, including the
freight and insurance. which have been paid.
1t consists principally Of corn, meal, flour,
rice, and the like articles. May prosperous

ltn"aoM # HnMmAhS "A Columbus, Ohio
paper states that ! boat which had arrived al
Stcnbenville, had on board the bones ola non
dcscript animal, one Of which was twenty fect il,
length, eight in wdth, and weighed upwards OF
1900 pounds. The back bone was sixteen inch
es in diameter, and the ribs nine feet in length.
1t is calculated from the size Of the bones that
the animal, when living, must have been about
ttiy isct in length, twenty 10 tWcnty.siX feet
IN width, and about twenty feet in height; and il
must have weighed at least twenty tons. These
bones were found near the Mississippi river, in
Louisiana, and form the greatest natiIal curiosi
ty ever bcheld. This animal must have as far
transcended the mammoth IN seize, as the man
moth common dog.

On the subject of the unpleasant d;g.v
ence between the State of Georgia and tho
United States, the Editors of the N.t;onaI ."I
lntelligencer say that they are in nossss sss'
sion of letter from a gentleman in r,,, Geos
gia to his friend in Washington, dated ,hs
18th of February, which contains the follow.
ing.


"Since writing the above, had conyer.
sation with Col. Samuel A. Bailey. who has
Just returned and completed his second mis-.
sion to the Little Prince. He saws. 7 NAV
state, that he, the Little Prince. and the na :.
tlon, are perfectly reconciled and satisfied
with the survey Of the lands, and that their
only object was to protest against the survey
tor the purpose of having a legal claim (so
far as that would effect it) on the United
States, for the payment OF the value Of ths
land west of the new treaty line, and il any
difficulty ensues, it will be effected BY thely
States Government.

full articles.article:
which are delightful. Accompanied by MacIn-
tos!, soon made acquaintance with the Indi-
ans Of this country; we found some exercising
themselves in drawing The bow. wished to
try my strength like the rest; Macintosh also
armed himself with bow; he has the arm and
eye sight of William Tell. Some Of the trials of
skill which he exhibited, If told, would scarcely
be believed. particularly admired the dexter
~, with which while laying on the green plat,
he threw an arrow, which striking the earth a
little distance, rose with light bound and flew
TO prodigious distance. ltisa way, which the
Indians employ to throw far, and without being
seen by the enemy ] triei! in vain this singil-
lar feat: each time my arrow instead Of rebound
ing sank III the earth

full articles.headline: INSTINCT.
full articles.article:
1t is the custom in boarding houses 10 give no.
tce ofthc hour Of meals BY ringing bell. A
cat belonging to the house, being accustomed to
get his food in the dining room, soon became At.
tentiyc to the sound that summoned the family
to othe parlor II happened one day that he had
been shut upin room, and was therefore pre-
vented from attending to the voice of the anx-
iously expected bell; and on being released from
his prison some hours after, he immediately has.
tened to the dining room; but unfortunately eve
ry thing had disappeared, and the poor cat found
himself obliged 70 go without his breakfast To
wards the middle Of the day the bell was sudden
ly heard ringing; and on the servants running out
TO ascertain the cause, they found the cat hang.
ing by the rope, and sunlmoning the family to a
second repast!

full articles.headline: Raleigh AZ. c. J March s
full articles.article:
Owing to the scarcity Of Corn in this sec
tion OF the country, no doubt many expedi-
ents VIII be adopted to prevent its consump-
ton we Yesterday heard o. one, which we
trust, for the credit of tho State, and for the
sake OF humanity, stands alone; but we think
It ought to be mentioned, that travellers
may be put on their guard A gentleman
stopped at a house in an adjacent county.
which promised "entcrtainment tor man
and beast" and requested that his horse
might be ted. Before ordering him out to
resume his Journey, he Went to the stable to
see how he Jared and was surprised to find,
that though there was sufficicncy of corn
and fodder before him, he had eat nothing. He
was at loss to account for this voluntary
abstinence, and putting his hand into the
trough to ascertain the cause, he found the
bottom OF It nicely coated With fresh Tar. 1t
was spread ON so thinly as to be impercept


ble to the eye, but it is known that the
horse has such great antpathy to this sub
stance, that he will touch nothing imnrcp-
mated Will. t.-hcgister.

without which, the world" would surely be
"sad, and the garden" as wild as Camp
bell could we'll imagine it. Indeed it is hop
ed, that after spending such an evening a.
mong.


vie


With fancy's pencil, and give birth to things
Lovely beyond its fairest pctulings-"
many of the brotherhood will soon have oc-
casion to say with Benedict :-"When
said would die a bachelor, did not think
should live long enough to be married"


We do not positively know, however,
whether any conquests were made on either
side; but we thought now and then, that
"love has eyes" And once, when gen
tleman whose struggling tell-tale hairs had
disappeared for the evening, and received
some kind and f1attering expressions from a
nymph of laughing eye and carnation lips,
we thought, from the life and Joy which
it seemed to have impaired. that the gentle
swain, had he been poetical, would have ex
claimed:--


"Speak to me thus and will be loves slave;
Pll build him altars-hc shall have all flowers
Of vale, or hill, or fountain and all fruits
That melt in Autumn's basket; nay, the gold
ot ilcsperls' gardenwere too Slight y gift
10 honor herr"


Supper was served at ] O'clock, in spa.
clous apartment formed by throwing the
blue and crimsoned saloons of the City Ho-
tel into one. The tables were beautifully
covered with rich vands and fruits, and the
wines were "ruby bright" Every thing, in
inc, went Oft aGrccably comfortably and sat
lsfactorily

The following aneedoteisquoted froh the
new Philadelphia Quarterly. The review
of American Biography, from winch thls Is
taken, containsa number of interesting lncl-
dents and characters.


When the British army had possession OF
Philadelphia, Gen. Howe's headquarters
were in Second d-street, the fourth door below
Spruce in house which was before occupi-
ed by Gen. Cadwallader Directly oppo-
site, resided William and Lydia Darrah,
members of the society of Friends. A supe-
rlor officer of the British Army, believed to
be the adjutant General, fixed upon one OF
their chambers, a back room, for private
conference and two Of them frequently met
there, with fire and candles in close consul
taton. About the ID Of December, the adj
iutant general told Lydia that they would be
in the room at o'clock, and remain late;
and that they wished the family to retire
early to bed; adding that when they were
going away they would call her to let them
out, and extinsuish their fire and candles.
She accordingly sent all the family to bed;
but as the officer had been SO particular, her
curiosity was excited.


She took off her shoes. and put her ear to
the key -holc of the conclave, and overheard
an order read for all the British troops to
march out late in the evening of the fourth,
and attack General Washngton's army,
then encamped at White Marsh. On hear
ing this she returned to her chamber, and
laid down. Soon after, the officers knock ed
at the door, but She rose only at the third
summons, having teigned herself asleep.
Her mind was SO much agitated, that from
this moment. she could neither ca. nor sleep;
supposlng it to be III her power to save the
lives of thousands of her fellow countrymcn;
but not knowing how She was to convey the
Information to General Washington. not
dating to confdc il to her husband. The time
left, however, was short. She quickly de-
termned to make her way, as soon as posi-
Bile, to the American outposts. She inform
ed her family, that as she was in want Of
-four She would so to Franktord for some;
her husband insisted that she should take
the servant maid with her, but to his sur
prise she positively refused. She got acces.
70 General Howe, and solicited, what he
readily granted, apass through the British
troops on the lines. Leaving her bag at the
null, she FASTENED towards the American
lines, and encountered on her way an A.
merican lieutenant colonel (Craiy) OF the
light horse, who, with some OF his men, was
~ the look out for information. He knew
her, and inquired where she was going, She
answered, in quest Of her son, an officer in
the American army, and praying the colonel
% alisht and walk with her. He did so, or
derlng his troops to keep in sight. 10 him
She disclosed he, secret, after ha, ing obtain
ed from him solemn promise never To be-
tray her individually, as her life might be 1T
stake with the British.


He conducted hen To house near at hand,
directed something for her to eat, and has
tened 70 head quarters. when he brought
General Washington acquainted with what
he had heard. Washington made, Of course,
all preparation for battling the medtatetl sur
prise. LHdlA returned home With her flour;
sat up alone to watch the tnovtrnt nts If the
I'ritlsl. troops; heard their footsteps; but
when they returned in a few hours after, did
not dare TO ask QUESTION, though s0licitous
to know the event. The next evening the
Adlntant General came in, and requested
her 70 walk up to his room, AS he wished to
put some questions, She followed him in
terror; when he locked the door and begged
her, With an air Of mystery, to be seated
She va, sure she was either suspected or
hetrayed.-He inquired earnestly, whether
any Of her family were up the last night lie
and the other officer met; she told him thai
they all retired at O'Clock. lie Observed,
"l know you were asleep for | knocked al
your chamber door three times before Won
heard me: ! am entirely at loss to imagine
who gave Gen. WASHINGTON information Of
cur intended attack, unless the walls of the
house could speak.-Whcn we arrived near
White Marsh, we found all their cannon
mounted, and the troops prepared TO receive
US, and We have marched back like par
eel CT FOOLS

full articles.headline: THE BACHELORS BALI. AT NEW YORK
full articles.article:
yon mansion made by beaning tapers gay,


browns the dim night, and counterfrts the tlav,
From lunn'd windows, glancing on tho eve,
Around, ahwart, the frisking shadows hy,-


Here mirth and tlncy's wanton train atlvaAcc,
And 10 light measures turn the swimming dance.


Saf4se.


Ii viii be recolcotcd that at one Of the
meetings Of the venerable fraternity Of
bachelors {savs the Commercial Advcrtls-
er,) called for the purpose of resisting the
encroachment meditated on their rights, bv
the leading member of the legislature, it
was resolved to show the world that tbey
were not yet destitute Of life and soul and
public spirit, by giving bali. the proceeds
OF which should be devoted to the support of
the mothers and sisters of those bachelors
Of Greece, who are fighting the battles of
freedom and their country. From the lay
of the resolution until the consummation Of
the project. the fraternity have been as bu-
silly engaged in procuring decorations for the
Assembly Room, and rendering themselves
agreeable in the outward man, as though
they were about to lay siege to the whole
race of unmarried females at once. And to
do them justice, they succeeded to admira
ton The ball was got up with elegance
and splendor, and whether the bachelors re-
serted to the same stratagcm that the Ro-
man bachelors did when they made viii
/ ling captives of the Sabine women, or not
we cannot say; but certain it is, that those
Sabines must have had charming daughters
if their artiul after sons in-aw stole such ar
! assemhlsge of pretty women. The ball wa,
given at the City Hotel; and Mr.. Jennings
Being himself gay bachelor, spared nei
ther pains, nor labor, nor expense. in III,
preparations for sustaining the honor of hi.
brethren.


4 The ladies, certainly large majority o
them, to say nothing of the native charms o
beautiful forms, bright eyes, captivatin,
smiles and blooming cheeks. were arrayet
with good taste and elegant simplicity
White pretlominated, with head dresses O
flowers, feathers, pearls, and brlliants.
would be invidious to particularize; suffice i
then 20 say, that youth. and beauty, and love
liness, mingled in gay communioa. and the
slendid forms appeared like sylphs from
happier sphere, assembled to cheer the hun
dreds of gay bachelors. who from this chill
ling appellation have been supposed coli
and dead to the fasciua,ions Of that sc,,

AN ACT making appropriations for the support
Of The Navy Of the United States, for the year


one thousand eight hundred and tw enty-scven.
~ il enacf4d tn thr lScnatc and House of
Representatives. IF Ae Unted States of II
merica in Congress assembled, That tor
defrysng the expenses of the Navy, for the year
one thousand eight hundred and twenty seven,
the following sums be, and the same arc hereby,
respectively appropriated;


Forthe pay and subsistence ofthc officers, and
pay of the seamcn, other than those at Navy
Yards, Shore Stations, and in ordinary, one mil
lion one hundred and twelve thousand three hun
hundred and nincty.two dollars and twenty-five
cents.


For the paw, subsistence, and allowance of Of
fcers, and pay OF scamen. and others, at Navy
Yards, Shore Stations, Hospitals, and III ordina
rs, one hundred and scyentv-two thonsand nine
hundred ana twenty -ioure dollars and twenty-five
cents.


For the pay Of NJyal Constructors, Snperln-
temtcnt5, sn,. all the civil establishments II ths


everi,l Navy Yards, fifty eight thousand and thr.
/ ty-one dollars and fifty cents.


For provisions, five hundred and seventy-ninc
thousand one hundred and forty eight dollars aud
fifty four cents


For repairs Of vessels in ordinary, and for the
wear and tear Of vcsselsin commission, four hun
,lred and fifty thousand dollars.
4 For medicines. surgical Instruments, hospital
I stores, and ior all other rSpenSc, on account Of
] the sick, fifty thog,and dollars.
4 For ordnance and tor ordnance stores, thirty
! FIVE Thousand dollars.


4 For repairs and Improvements Of Navy Yards,
two hundred and tllirty-oae thousand seven hun.
/ lre dollars and scycnty-tNo o cents.


a. Il ..-A
cruc during the year one thousand eight Atlu-
dred and twenty seven, iur the following pur-
poses:


For freight and transportation 'of materials and
stores Of every description; for wharfage and
dockage; for storage and rent for travelling cX-
penscs of officers, and transportation OF scalnen;
for house rent or chamber money, and for tuci
and candles 10 officers, other than those attached
to Navy Yards and shore statlons for colnms.
sons clerk hire, Office rent, stationary and fuel,


to Navy Agents; for premiums and incidental cA-
pcnses ofrecruiting; tor ipprehcndnE dcseittrs:
for compensation to Judge Advocates for per
diem allowance for persons attending Court,


Martial and Courts Of Inquiry, and to officers en-.


gagged iii extra service, beyond the limits ot then


stations; for PRINTING! and fur stationary Of every
description; tor books, CHARTS nautical and math.


ematc..l Instruments chronometcrs, models and
drawings for purchase and repairs Of steam and
tire engines, and for machinery; for purchase and


maintenance Of oxen and horses, and for carts,
wheels, and workmcn's tools otevery description
for postage of letters public service; for pilot.
age; for cabin furniture Of vessels i'll commission;
for taxes on Navy Yards and public property; for


assistance rendered 10 public vessels in distress,


for incidental labor at Navy Yards, not applicable
to any othcr appropriation; tor coal and other


fuel for torgcs, tn.nJrics, steam engines, and for
candles, oil, and uc for vessels il commission
and in ordinary; and i0r no other object or pur.
pose whatever, two hundred and tWcnty thou
sand dollars.


Forcontingent expenses for objects M,ising in


the year one thousand cisnt hunire,i and twcn-


ty-seven, and not herein befoic enumerated, five


thousand dollars.


For pay and subsistence of the Marine Corps,


one hundred and twenty thousand dollars.


For rclothing for the same. twenty-clyht thou
sand seven hundred ami siSiy-iive dollars.
Il For fuel for the SAME, SIX Thousand dollars


For contingencies for the same, fourteen tllo,l-
sand dollars.


For medicines for tie same, two thousand three


hundred and sixty nine dollars


For barracks for the same, forty -onc thousand
dollars.


/ For carving into effect joint resolution Of


Congress, Of May twcnty-sccond, eighteen hun.


lred and twentE E-sx directing surveys and esti-
; mates for dry docks, two thousand seven hun.
drcd and seven dollars and tW enty-scvcn cents.
For the agency on the coast Of Africa, and ex.
pcnces Of supporting in the United States, and


transporting to the coast of Africa, those persons
who have been released and subject to be traps
ported by the provisions Of the act of eighteen
hundred and nineteen, thrty-sX Thousand sever
hundred and ten dollars. For arrcarages prior


to the first of January, eighteen hundred and
twenty seven, twenty thousand dollars.
SEC. Q. -And6e Hfarther enactcd, That
! balance Of the appropriation for the Navy DE
4 partment to be carried to the surplus fund or


the first Of January, one Thousand eight hundrct
). and twenty seven, be, and tic same arg hereb,
). c-appropriated.


= :, SEC. ). Ind be il further enacted, Tha
Z several sums hereby appropriated, shall be pait
: out of any money in the Treasury not othcrwis,
: appropriated; Pr3vided, however, that n,


money appropriated by this act shall be paid t,


any person, for his compensation, who is in ar
! .ears to the United States until such perso
: shall have accounted and paid into the Treasur
u all Sums for which he may be liable Prouidet
> also, that nothing in this section contained shal
be construed 10 extend to balances arising
solely from the depreciation of Treasury notes
= received by such person TO DC expended in tn
public service but ia all cases where the pa
or salary Of anv person is ~ithhcld, in puisuanc
Of this act, it shall be the duty of the accounting
: officer, if demanded by the party, his agent c


attorney, to report, forthwith, to The agent of th
: Treasury Department, the BALANCE due: and

shat OF Great Britaia in the East Indies. But |
40 one in rendering them this justice can
help taking interest in the fate of the Indians. |
EAus, meeting az every step the bark hut of
wandering hunter who inhabits it in secn |
rIty. ana III the simple virtues Of ignorance,
We cannot think without sorrow that they
viii soon be overturned and replaced by an
American cultipator's farm.


II was heara rapid creek, the borders OF which
we're Steep that we saw for the first time the In
dans united in a body to receive the General. A
great number ot women and young boys broke
through the trees on the opposite border Of the
aver, and, upon seeing rs, they raised cries Of
10Y. Some warriors descended the brow of
i.lll at little distance and to spot on the
river side where the boat was, iii which we were
20 land-Thc variety and singular richness Of
their costumes offered most picturesque view.
hlr George Lafayette splan!s first upon the land,
and III moment was surrounded by men, wo
incn and children, who moved round him, dane
ed about him, touched his hands and his garments
with an air Of surprise, and delight which caus
Cd him almost as much embarrassment rs emo.
ton Suddenly, as il they wished to give more
dgnhed and solemn expression to their Joy they
retired behind the men ranged in front. lie
who appeared to be the chief Of the tribe, By
shr and prolonged cry gave the signal for a sort
OF salute which was repeated by the whole troops
when they rushed again towards the boat.-Im-
mediately upon the Generals descending, some
of the strongest brought little low chair, which
we had with us, and obliged him to mount it,
"not wishing they said, shat their father
should put his foot on the damp earth.' The
General was thus carried as in a paanquin, to a
certain distance from the river side, then he
whom have already distinguished as the chief
Of the tribe approached, and told him in English,
that all his brothers were happy at being visited
by him, who in his affection for the inhabitants
of America, had never distinguished blood or
color; who was the cherished father OF mcn who
nhabitthe continent After the chief had spok
en-, the other Indians came to press the hand OF
the General and to place it on their heads. They
would not abandon the carriage, but dragged ii
themselves, mounted by short steps the hill from
which which we had seen them descend, and ON
which was situated one OF their largest hamets,


Whilst We walked, approached the Indian
Chief thought that, since lie spoke English, he
had been brought up like liamly in the United
States, and SO was informed lie was about 28
years of aye, Of middle size his limbs per
fectv beautiful, his phys,ognony noble, and hi,
airsorowfi.l. When he did not speak he cast
down his large black eyes, which were covered
With thick eyc-lashes. When he toll me that he
was the eldest son Of Macintosh, could not re-
cal, without pain, the mPrecations that | had
heard from the watch, against the Ctiet OF the
Maacogulges 1t was this, undoubtedly, which
gave the young man the air Of detection and
meditation; but, after what coali gather, from
his conversation, explained il to myself still
better his Intelligence only developed itself a
the expense ofhis security. lie appreciated the
true position fthis nation; he perceived it was
growing weaker, and forcsaw its approaching
distinctions he feh how inferior it was to those
which surrounded III he had learned how impos
slble it was to change the wandering lite ot men
of his race. The neighborhood ofclylzed men
had not done them any good, and had introduced
among them vices to which they we're strangers


He seemed to hope that the treaty, which cast
them back into country wholly desert, would
restore the ancient organization Of the tribes, or
at least guaranty their preservation in the state
n which they now were.


In the meantime. we arrived at the top Of the
hlll-there we saw helmets, and swords, and
horsemen, ranged along the road; they were
not Indians, but civilized men sent from the state
Of Alabama, to meet the General. The slngu-
lar triumphant march, to which he had been
obliged to submit, then ceased. The Indians
could not see without Jealousy. the American
escort place themselves around him; but we ap.
preached their village, and they hastened to
approach il before rs. There, at our afrval, we
found them met together, having thrown aside
their garments and prepared to exhibit before
rs their warlike games. We reached vast
plain, about which was scattered q hundred In.
dian habitations, improved BY the verdure Of the
thick groves We noticed house larger than
the others; it was that Of the American resident;
he at the same time kept an inn, and his wife had
the direction ofa school, in which they attempt
ed tc instruct the children Of the Indians All
the men were assembled in this place, having
thrown aside part Of their vestnents; their faces
painted with colors Enthusiastically mixed and some
wearing, by way Of distinction, plumes in their
hair, They told us that they were going to play
in honor Of their white father And we really
saw them separate into two armies, form two
camps in two extremities Oft the place, name two
chiefs, and provoke each other to combat. The
cry which was raised by each Of the two divisions,
and which they told us was the war-cry Of the
Indian tribes, is perhaps, the strongest modnla-
ton of the human voice, that it is possible to
hear, and the effect which it produced upon the
warriors, Young and old, is more extraordinary
still. The sports commenced-They explained
to us that the game was, for the two parties to
throw ball, something like that of our scholars,
10 certain mark, and that he who struck this
mark seven times should be victorious We in
reality saw the combatants, each armed with
two long and heavy rockets prcc tate them.
selves with light movement, leap one above
the other, in order to seize It in the air, with


unprecedented skill, and scnd il to the mark ~
when the ball was missed by player, it rolled
on the pround-Then they all lowered theil

full articles.headline: THE REMAINS or ALLEN.
full articles.article:
It affords US much qualification to state, that
the Navy Department have promptly accecded
to the request of the Common Council Of this
city, 10 have the remains Of our fellow citizen,
Lieut.. WILLIAM II. ALLEN, brought from Ma.
taneas to New York, in a public vessel; and that
a Letter from MIR. Secretary Southland to the May.
or OF this city, assures him that the earliest op.
portnnity vii! be improved to have this service
pertorlncd in manner gratifying to the friends
and fellow citizens Of Lieut.. All, i, and with All
respect due to the memory Of the larnentcd he.
ro. o.-Cohlmtian Republican,.

Noollen Factory, at Jewett City, Conn. belong.
ing to Breed, Trumbull & White, was entirely
consumed, with the machinery and large GUAM

supposed to have originated from the stove
pipe in the third loft. Loss estimated at soOO 900
which was insured at Hartford.

On May day, 1913, there was shameful
riot committed by the London apprentices,
servants, watermen, and priests, against for
elgners, by pulling down and rining their
houses. The complaints against them were,
"that there were such numbers OF them EN-.
ployed as arttlcers, that the English could
set no work; that the English merchants
had little TO do, by reason of the merchant
strangers bringing in all silks cloths Of gold,
VINE, oil, iron; that no man almost buyeth OF
an Engllshman; they also export SO much
wool, tin. and lead, that English adventurers
can have no living; that foreigners compass
the city round about, in Southwark. West
minister, Temple Bar, Holborn, st. Martins,
st. John-Street. Aldgate. Tower Hill, and
st. GATHERINGS: and they forestall the mar
ket. 50 that no good thing for them cometh
TO the market, which are the causes why
Engiishmen want and starve, whilst foreign
ers live in abundance and pleasure that
the Dutchmen bring over Iron, timber, ana
leather ready manufactured, and nails, locks
baskets. cupboards, stools. tables, chests,
grdles. saddles, and painted cloths" y
saw" said John Lincoln, (the chief instigat-
or, )"on Sunday this Lent, six hundred Tor
eigners shooting At the poppinjay with cross
bows" This riot was over by dawn o. day
Several of the rioters were hanged. and the
King pardoned the rest. The pretenlea
crimes of these foreigners were, their WORK
ing cheaper and being more indusfrlom
than our o1ca teotle, whose exclusive PRIV.
ileges within the city kept the foreigners !"
those ont-ports above named. out OF the ires.
dom; thereby getting much Of the 'raoS
from the freemen.--.4nnais Of Commerce.

TIE Grec& .SuhiH SAln.-The elegant
ship Chancellor, Capt Baker hauled out in
the stream yesterday, and will probably sail
to-day, with provisions, &c. for the Greeks.
Mr.. Miller, of Vermont. who was three
years IN Greece, and eighteen months in ac-
tual service, goes out in the vessel He will
have the charge oi the supplies. and pay at
tentlon TO their distribution. The cargo is
SAID 70 be worth $4,000, including the
freight and insurance. which have been paid.
1t consists principally Of corn, meal, flour,
rice, and the like articles. May prosperous
gales attend her, We have already stated
thata second vessel viii be despatched as
soon IS pr lctcable, in which Lieut. Carpen-
ter, OF the nitcd States Navy, who has just
returned from the Mcd,tel rancan station,
Will goas agent Can. .hh.


ltn"aoM # HnMmAhS "A Columbus, Ohio
paper states that ! boat which had arrived al
Stcnbenville, had on board the bones ola non
dcscript animal, one Of which was twenty fect il,
length, eight in wdth, and weighed upwards OF
1900 pounds. The back bone was sixteen inch
es in diameter, and the ribs nine feet in length.
1t is calculated from the size Of the bones that
the animal, when living, must have been about
ttiy isct in length, twenty 10 tWcnty.siX feet
IN width, and about twenty feet in height; and il
must have weighed at least twenty tons. These
bones were found near the Mississippi river, in
Louisiana, and form the greatest natiIal curiosi
ty ever bcheld. This animal must have as far
transcended the mammoth IN seize, as the man
moth common dog.

ence between the State of Georgia and tho

"Since writing the above, had conyer.
